date: stated on April 11, 2019 in a town hall in New Hampshire:
title: Did half of the United States population suffer from diabetes or diabetes, as Tim Ryan claimed?
text: Democratic Congressman Tim Ryan, if elected president, says that he will focus on a health-care system that not only covers people when they are ill, but also preserves their health. Most health-care costs are related to preventable chronic diseases, and Ryan in New Hampshire has claimed. "The half of the country today has either diabetes or pre-diabetes," said Ryan, a U.S. representative from Ohio, on April 11, at the WMU Municipal Hall in Manchester. "The diabetes costs 2.3 times every other patient. This will sink the health care system." According to research carried out by the American Association of Diabetes, people diagnosed with diabetes were approximately 2.3 times more expensive than people without diabetes or any other chronic disease. We wanted to focus on Ryan I's claim: Does half the United States population really suffer from diabetes or diabetes? The allegation of Ryan is almost correct for adults, but there are limited data on children. The American Association of Diabetes told us that it would be more accurate to say that almost half of all adults in the United States have either diabetes or pre-diabetic disease. A large number of adults with diabetes, and Ryan ' s pre-diabetic campaign addressed us to the CDC, National Diabetes Statistics Report 2017, the latest available national report. It highlights estimates of people with diabetes and diabetes in 2015, when the total population of the United States was about 321 million. The CDC stated that most estimates of diabetes in the report do not distinguish between type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes; however, data are likely to be more discriminatory than type 2, as type 2 represents 90 to 95 per cent of all cases of diabetes. Diabetes occurs when the blood sugar level is higher than usual, but it is not high enough to be diagnosed as type 2 diabetes. The report states that some 30.3 million people of all ages, or 9.4 per cent of the population, contracted diabetes in 2015. The measurement of people suffering from diabetes is slightly different: only those aged 18 or over. The CDC reported that some 84.1 million people aged 18 or over suffer from diabetes. This was approximately 34 per cent of the adult population in the United States in 2015. These figures are about 43 per cent of the United States population in 2015, and do not include people under the age of 18 with diabetes, as stated by the spokesman for the Ryan Julia Krieger campaign. Kim wrote: 1 February 2021 "Kungherman Ryan usually says "about half of the population when referring to these statistics, especially since there are fewer documents/trust figures when it comes to diabetes or pre-diabetes in children," as Krieger said. The CDC has specific data to estimate the prevalence of diabetes and diabetes among adults. According to the CDC report, in 2015, 12.2 per cent of the adult population was diabetic, diagnosed or undiagnosed. In addition, 12.2 per cent of adults with diabetes are about 46 per cent of the adult population with diabetes or diabetes. The report does not contain data on children with diabetes or undiagnosed diabetes. There is little data on children, "because diabetes has traditionally been an old-age disease," as Domenico Aquili, Professor of Medicine at Columbia University and Director of the Diabetes Research Centre at Columbia University. However, studies have found that the incidence of diabetes in children is much lower than in adults. Only those with overweight or obesity, as Stephen Benoit, a medical officer at the Centre for Disease Control, is recommended for screening for diabetes. The findings of the CDC are derived from national surveys, and there are therefore restrictions on the application of estimates to the total population in 2015. Figures can swing in either direction when different assumptions are used. The CDC recommends that diabetics should eat healthy food and be more active in preventing or delaying diabetes. Our judgment Ryan said, "The half of the country today has either diabetes or diabetes." There are a large number of people with diabetes or diabetes. Ryan's claim may give the impression that half of the country, including children and adults, has either of these conditions. However, there are limited data on persons under the age of 18 suffering from diabetes or undiagnosed diabetes. Ryan's statement is more accurate if it is limited to the adult population that about 46 percent of adults have either diabetes or diabetes. In general, Ryan's statement is accurate but needs clarification. We're mostly assessing it right.
